findings.title: BuyBack.sol and LandToken.sol: Contracts can lock ETH that cannot be extracted
findings.description: The contracts implement payable functions (receive() and constructor) without any way to extract the funds, meaning that any value sent to the contract will be stuck forever.

findings.title: Order of arithmetic operation may decrease precision
findings.description: Multiplications are performed on the result of division throughout the codebase, which decreases precision slightly.

findings.title: LandToken.sol: Missing zero-check in mint role transfer
findings.description: The contract allows for just one minter which can be transferred. However, there is no check for the `address(0)` in the `passMinterRole()` function.

findings.title: stake.sol: Ineffective access protection on read-only functions
findings.description: The view functions getAmountWithdrawn() and getStakers() have ineffective access protection as they perform a check require(msg.sender==owner); which does not prevent reading these variables since nothing on the blockchain is private.

findings.title: Contract owner can manipulate stakers profits by temporarily changing currentAPR and landAPR values
findings.description: The contract owner can temporarily change currentAPR and landAPR to high or low values, allowing them to harvest huge APR or prevent certain stakers from earning APR.

findings.title: Pragma allows for a wide range of compiler versions
findings.description: The `pragma` statement allows for a very large range of compiler versions, including some versions with known bugs.

findings.title: LandTokenStake.sol: no need to use SafeERC20 for LandToken
findings.description: The codebase uses `SafeERC20` to interact with `LandToken`, but this is unnecessary since it's a trusted token and its behavior is clear, which can be removed in the interest of gas cost.

findings.title: Neither Withdraw nor Harvest events are emitted
findings.description: The events `Withdraw` and `Harvest` are unused and not emitted in the corresponding functions.

findings.title: Contract.sol: Code Cleanup
findings.description: The contract contains many unused variables, unnecessary library associations, hardcoded values, and duplicate code which reduces readability and increases the chance of error.

findings.title: Remove any unused variables
findings.description: The contract contains many unused variables such as `LandTokenStake.S`, `LandTokensStake.SA`, `stake.thing` and `stake.actives`.

findings.title: No need to associate a library with the type if it’s not used
findings.description: Remove the `SafeMath` association with `uint256` type if it’s not used.

findings.title: Remove all magic numbers, strings and addresses
findings.description: The contract contains many hardcoded values which reduces the readability and increases the chance of error. It is recommended to use reusable variables for these.

findings.title: Infinite Approval Simulation
findings.description: The method `buyback.approveTokens` uses a very large number to simulate infinite approval, which can lead to unintended consequences.

findings.title: Duplicate code in `stake.sol`
findings.description: It is recommended to extract the interest calculation to a method and reuse it where required.

findings.title: Unwanted mapping in `stake.sol`
findings.description: The mappings `harvestAmountBUSD` and `harvestAmountLand` is not required since the value is only used inside a method and is always set to 0. It is recommended to use local variables instead of state variables for them.
